stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the stream building and brainstorming the Course 13 boss fight against Raphael the Raven.  He models a snowy tower with a nest, imports the Ice Castle music track, and debates technical and design constraints—especially how to recreate Raphael’s moon battle in 3-D on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Course 13 is in production; the team is now designing the Raphael the Raven boss and its arena.

Boss concept: fight starts on an icy tower, Raven eclipses the moon, Mario is flung upward, dodges falling stars, lands on a low-gravity ‘frozen cheese’ moon, and damages Raven by throwing thawed star-shards; three hits end the fight and the reward star hatches from an egg in the tower’s nest.
development_findings.quote: The Raven jumps on the tower, anti-gravity activates, you fall up, dodge the stars, land on the moon, pick up the unfrozen cheese ninja star and throw it at him.

development_findings.summary: Kaze chooses to keep gravity changes local to the boss actor to avoid global engine edits; he plans to request Arthur’s existing planetary-gravity code.
development_findings.quote: We need to make sure the things we add can be done entirely on an actor level.

development_findings.summary: He rejects a ‘hollow moon’ interior because of render-order and physics complexity, favouring an outside-only moon surface with light gravity.
Fast64 bug: when material blending is used, fog sometimes remains enabled in later display-list segments, causing visual errors on N64 hardware (not visible in Blender).
development_findings.quote: There's a Fast64 bug that makes Geomode fog always on... that's why my Course 12 looks so bugged on N64.

development_findings.summary: Music pipeline: ~80-90 % of the OST is M64 (MIDI-like) via Seq64; ~20 % are streamed tracks in a large ‘f-up format’. Current build holds 98 songs—already more than Mario Odyssey’s 82.
Imported a new Ice Castle track, manually determined loop points (08.866 s to 93.633 s) and confirmed stereo playback; refuses mono because it ‘would sound so ass’.
Star/collectible plan: 15 levels, ~180 traditional stars plus 75 five-coin collectibles (Yoshi coin equivalent) for a total content volume comparable to Mario Odyssey.
Camera & controls: analog camera support deemed infeasible on original hardware because N64 has only one stick; players can use D-pad for slow camera movement instead.
Kaze exports models directly to C files via Fast64 Python script, eliminating intermediate formats and maximising performance.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy values player freedom over mandatory difficulty or heavy direction; he criticises hacks that ‘pad star count’ and thinks challenge should emerge from player-chosen risky movement.
context_findings.quote: If you want the game to be more difficult, then do more risky jumps… you’re free in Mario 64, that’s the great part.

context_findings.summary: He refuses to set a release date or publish unfinished builds, referencing dislike of ‘EA-style’ early releases.
context_findings.quote: I can’t release it before it’s finished… then I would release an unfinished product, the thing that everybody hates EA for.

context_findings.summary: Personal life: Kaze and Zeina have a newborn (~2 weeks); he jokes about not being able to breast-feed and notes Zeina currently has ‘a lot more work’ than he does.
Physical health: recovering from a knee injury, continues big-four lifts plus weighted pull-ups.
He avoids Nintendo’s Giga-Leak data to reduce legal risk: ‘Even just knowing about things in the Giga leak can get you in trouble.’

biobak.summary: Supplied a reference video that sparked the current Raven boss design.

badub.summary: Composed the new Ice Castle and other tracks; Kaze praises his creativity.
badub.quote: Badub’s music is great; the creativity he brings to the table is very, very sick.

zeina.summary: Handles much of the animation workload despite caring for their newborn.

key_stories.title: Reinventing Raphael
key_stories.summary: Kaze wrestles with how to translate Yoshi’s Island’s 2-D Raven fight into a 3-D N64 hack. After discarding several ideas (hollow moon, interior gravity flips), he settles on an outside-moon battle with anti-gravity transitions.
key_stories.challenge: Adapting a beloved 2-D set-piece to 3-D within N64 limits.
key_stories.process: Discussed camera angles, gravity hacks, projectile behaviour, visual storytelling and asset reuse while modelling a tower and nest live on stream.
key_stories.outcome: Defined a three-phase design and drafted implementation notes to share with the team.
key_stories.key_quote: It kind of has to be the moon… but we need to make sure everything can be done on an actor level.

key_stories.title: Fast64 Fog Bug
key_stories.summary: Visual glitches in Course 12 revealed a fog-state bug in Fast64’s material-blending export.
key_stories.challenge: Unexpected permanent fog on real N64 hardware.
key_stories.process: Kaze and Lilaa traced the issue to a display-list where fog was never cleared after a blended material.
key_stories.outcome: Bug documented; workaround is to avoid specific material-blending sequence until fixed.
key_stories.key_quote: In this display list, it doesn’t turn the fog off—even if you have fog unchecked.

key_stories.title: Looping the Ice Castle Track
key_stories.summary: Kaze imports Badub’s new Ice Castle theme and fine-tunes its loop points live.
key_stories.challenge: Identify precise loop timing for seamless playback in M64 format.
key_stories.process: Listened, compared waveforms, calculated frame counts (08.866 s to 93.633 s) and converted to sample numbers before adding to the build.
key_stories.outcome: Track plays correctly in stereo and loops cleanly in-game.
key_stories.key_quote: None of the songs in this game are mono; mono would sound so ass.
